message.content:
```
aksw | Four. The theory of island biogeography and species richness depend on
0fsl | · Area size: Large size has larger populations and higher habitat heterogeneity
0m3g | · Distance to mainland: Nearness leads to higher colonization rate
9sp0 | Right arrow S up · Habitat connectivity: Low connectivity means lower colonization rate
nbpk | · Speciation-extinction dynamics: Related to time and population size/area
xs3r | Lecture Seven - Foraging Theory
ffuj | What is Optimal Foraging Theory, O. F. T.?
h7f6 | It is a behavioral ecology model that helps predict how an animal behaves when searching for food
t74k | Aim of the Optimal Foraging Theory
qdn7 | · To predict the foraging strategy of a forager/predator to be expected under specified conditions
dib4 | Important terminologies
yvqj | Ideal Free Distribution theory - theory which makes a case of uniform distribution of food for predators such that there is no need for foragers to switch foraging patches
vz2f | · Functional response - deals with a predator's intake rate in response to variation in prey distribution and densities
wyu0 | · Aggregate response - explains how predators are distributed in response to prey availability
s8xw | · Total response equals Functional response plus Aggregate response
afv1 | Assumptions inherent in Optimal Foraging Theory
fwf1 | One. The foraging behavior that is exhibited by present-day animals is the one that has been favored by natural selection in the past but almost enhances an animal's fitness at present
3wck | Two. High fitness is achieved by a high net rate of energy intake (gross energy intake minus the energetic costs of obtaining that energy)
jq2u | Three. Experimental animals are observed in an environment to which their foraging behavior is suited
9zf9 | Scenarios which unjustify the O.F.T.
clwo | One. Other aspects of the organism's behavior may influence fitness more than optimal foraging does. For example, premium on avoidance of predators coercing animals to forage at places and at times associated with lower predation risk, trading off efficiency in food gathering.
aki1 | Two. Variation in the efficiencies of energy gathering process exploiting different dietary constituents (for example, nitrogen) by many consumers (herbivores and omnivores) creating the need for consumers to forage on a mixed and balanced diet.
vf5h | Theoreticians and Mathematicians
l51p | O. F. T. makes predictions about foraging behavior based on mathematical models
s9zz | Important Question
x97k | Is it necessary for a real forager to be equally omniscient and mathematical, if it is to adopt the appropriate, optimal strategy?
qwix | Theoreticians are omniscient mathematicians - the foragers need not be
6lnq | The answer is NO, because
nxb1 | Theory says that if a forager that in some way manages to do the right thing in the right circumstances, then this forager
kwpw | One. Will be favored by natural selection
usfa | Two. Possible inheritance of newly acquired abilities by future generations
dnjr | Three. Abilities spread, in evolutionary time, throughout the population
qser | Parameterizing the O.F.T. One
8gam | Foraging entails predators expending time and energy in obtaining food
z4db | Intake rates of a predator is dependent on the searching (encounter rate) and handling (pursuing, subduing and consuming) times of prey
lw7l | Generalists pursue (and may then subdue and consume) a large proportion of the prey types they encounter
2exi | Specialists continue searching except when they encounter prey of their specifically preferred type
16py | Parameterizing the O.F.T. Two
m4ov | Specialists will only pursue profitable prey items, but may expend a great deal of time and energy searching for them
9uqd | Generalists will spend relatively little time searching but they will pursue both more or less profitable types of prey
8szx | An optimal forager should therefore balance the pros and cons so as to maximize its overall rate of energy intake
iwdc | Parameterizing the O.F.T. Three
4vks | Given that a predator already includes a certain number of profitable items in its diet, should it expand its diet (and thereby decrease its search time) by including the next most profitable item as well?
uyaf | The next most profitable prey item for an optimal forager
d1qh | Ei hi
nyqt | Profitability equals
7odd | where Ei is the energy content of the next most profitable ith prey item and hi its handling time
0le2 | In addition, E over h is the average profitability of the 'present' diet (one that includes all prey types that are more profitable than i, but does not include prey type i itself), and
5dw0 | S is the average search time for the present diet
i4yq | Parameterizing the O.F.T. Four
fj3g | If a predator does pursue a prey item of type i, then its expected rate of energy intake is Ei over hi
zuua | If it ignores this prey item, whilst pursuing all those that are more profitable, then it can expect to search further. The total expected rate of energy intake
elwn | E (s plus h)
jnqv | where E is the average energy content, s is the average search time and h is the average handling time for the present diet
unp3 | Parameterizing the O.F.T. Four
v8vk | The most profitable, optimal strategy for a predator will be to pursue the ith item if, and only if
sr40 | Ei over hi is greater than Ē over (s plus h)
5zjj | The optimal diet model leads to a number of predictions
f56l | One. Predators with shorter handling times than search times should be generalists, because the short times taken to handle prey items already found would allow them to commence searching for another prey.
ar2z | Two. Predators with longer handling times than search times should be specialists because once a prey has been seen and began to be handled (include pursuit), the predator cannot go in for another food. Therefore, such predators should go in for the most profitable prey.
yad0 | Parameterizing the O.F.T. Five
3g38 | Three. Predators should have broader diets in unproductive environments (where prey items are relatively rare and s is relatively large) than in a productive environment (where s is smaller)
vtbo | Four. Predators should ignore insufficiently profitable food types irrespective of their abundance
q8pa | Five. Provides a context for understanding the narrow specialization of predators that live in intimate association with their prey. Since their whole lifestyle and life cycle are finely tuned to those of their prey, handling time is low.
uc9x | Two studies of optimal diet choice that show a clear but limited
zy7o | correspondence with the predictions of the optimal diet model. Diets are more specialized at high prey densities; but more low profitability items are included than predicted by the theory
```
